#Text=County Durham
#Text=County
#Text=Durham
#Text=is a county in North East
#Text=England with a population of 510,800 .
#Text=It 's north of Yorkshire and south of Newcastle , astride the main north-south transport route .
#Text=The east is mostly farmland , interspersed by former mining towns .
#Text=Darlington
#Text=near its southern edge is the main conurbation , but Durham is its main visitor attraction .
#Text=The west is hilly , with sheep farms and remote moorlands .
#Text=Cities , towns and villages
#Text=The City of , population 29,000 , has a well-preserved ancient centre , dominated by its Norman castle and cathedral .
#Text=It 's also home to a large university .
#Text=The city is well worth a visit of a couple of days .
#Text=is the largest settlement in the county , popn 100,000 , yet it only counts as a town not a city .
#Text=Birthplace of the railways and always industrial , but affluent in its leafy west and south west , Darlington does n't have a university but there 's a large college .
#Text=Most of the county 's other towns are between Durham and Darlington , in fertile low-lying country along the A1 .
#Text=Beneath them is the Great Northern Coalfield , mined since medieval times , stretching up into Northumbria .
#Text=Hence the industry , the steam engines to pump those mines , and the railways to haul and consume the coals .
#Text=The underground mines have all closed , leaving the towns to scratch what living they can from new trades .
#Text=The main towns along this stretch are , , which has a railway museum , and .
#Text=Other towns in the north of the county are :
#Text=is a small former mining town near the coast .
#Text=Shotton Colliery is probably the world 's only coal mine converted for skydiving .
#Text=village has an impressive outdoor museum .
#Text=, midway between Durham and Newcastle , has Durham County Cricket Ground , where " Test " ie international cricket matches are also played .
#Text=The western part of County Durham is in the Pennines , the long chain of hills that forms the backbone of England .
#Text=There are lonely moors , and steep river valleys flowing out eastward , so the main road A68 follows a roller-coaster trajectory .
#Text=Here are :
#Text=, a market town that 's home to the grandiose Bowes Museum .
#Text=, former mining town on the northern edge of the county .
#Text=in a scenic valley , with High Force waterfall .
#Text=in Weardale , an old lead-mining town .
#Text=To the southeast , around the River Tees , is an industrial area which from 1974 to 1996 was a separate county , Cleveland .

#Text=Then this was abolished , and its towns south of the Tees were re-assigned to North Yorkshire . ( The assignation is notional since these towns are " unitary authorities " , not governed by a County Council . ) Towns to the north , re-assigned to County Durham , are :
#Text=: a post-industrial port , with an interesting dockyard museum .
#Text=actually straddles the Tees .
#Text=It 's very industrial ; but there 's a southern rural district , Yarm , now considered part of North Yorkshire .
#Text=The same 1974 re-organisation also removed Sunderland from County Durham .
#Text=It 's now part of Tyne & Wear .
#Text=Understand

#Text=Within England , only County Durham contains the word " county " in its title ( in the way many Irish counties do ) , because the powerful Norman " Prince Bishops " of Durham ruled it as a palatinate separate from the rest of England 's counties .

#Text=Originally it covered all the territory between the River Tees and the River Tyne , but over the centuries , and especially with modern changes to local government , it 's been whittled down and continually re-organised .

#Text=The name no longer precisely corresponds to a unit of local government , and probably the only two people who can say exactly where County Durham lies are the High Sheriff and Her Majesty 's Lord-Lieutenant , whose ceremonial duties relate to an older map of the world .
#Text=None of this is of the slightest concern to any traveller not gussied up in alderman 's ermine or dress military uniform .
#Text=For present purposes , " County Durham " on this page includes the post-2009 districts of Durham County ( sic ) , Darlington , Hartlepool and Stockton-on-Tees .
#Text=It does n't include Sunderland to the north or Middlesbrough , Redcar or Yarm to the south .
#Text=Talk
#Text=Listen very carefully to the local language : you 'll need to .
#Text=First , believe it or not , it is English you 're hearing .

#Text=The minority populations and languages in this area are small : during the 20th C the county was shedding labour from mining and ship-building in an era when others ( eg the textile towns ) were drawing it in from UK and abroad .
#Text=The only significant minority language is Polish , spoken by 1 % .
#Text=The local English dialect is " Geordie " , spoken in Durham , Newcastle and Northumbria ; the word also means a resident of those areas .

#Text=" Geordie " probably simply derives from " George " , a very common name for a local coal-miner , and there used to be a miners ' patois called " Pitmatic " or " Yakka " but it 's almost died out .
#Text=If you learn only one Geordie word , learn " Howay !

#Text=Read Beowulf and try to make sense of it - then have a local read it aloud in a heavy Geordie accent for a  Eureka !

column1: #Text=By train
#Text=This county saw the world 's first public railway , opened in 1825 .
#Text=The central spine of the county has excellent railway connections , being on the East Coast Main Line .
#Text=Frequent fast trains come up from London Kings Cross via York to Darlington ( 2 hrs 30 mins ) and Durham .
#Text=They continue north to Chester-le-Street , Newcastle and Edinburgh .
#Text=Other trains link Stockton , Middlesbrough and Sunderland .
#Text=A branch line train runs hourly from Darlington to Newton Aycliffe , Shildon and Bishop Auckland ( 30 min ) .
